Posts.Title: How Many Are We? zarovka SimonH

Posts.Content: Apr 24, 2014 10:32AM MAW wrote: You have picked a good site for support, information, and to help you realize how many of us are affected by stage IV breast cancer.  It gives you hope. My treatment and history is in my signature. We have a bit in common so far. After the Tamoxifen stopped working (my numbers kept creeping up) a new scan showed a spot on the liver and more spread to more bones. Time for a change from Tamoxifen to Letrozole. Been on it for not quite 3 months and my numbers dropped 56 the first month and then 69 the second month. We are at 199 which is my lowest ever. Body aches are back with the change to Letrozole (Tamoxifen did that too, and eventually the aches went away; but so did the effectiveness of the drug.) So I look at it this way, I'll ache forever as long as the drug is working. Set for a new scan in late May, we'll know more then. Best of luck to you.
Posts.Title: Invasive lobular Torridon MusicLover

Posts.Content: Jun 26, 2014 08:40AM MAW wrote: Agree with NYCchutzpah. Things calm down (especially when your drugs are working) and you find a new "normal". However, when drugs/treatment stop working, allow yourself to feel that panic and venerability. I think of it as a way to keep me in check as to what is really important in life. What to be mad about, what to appreciate, and what not to take for granted. A good cry does wonders, truly.    They are constantly finding new ways to treat our disease. And if WE keep sharing with each other things that we learn as patients (that the medical field doesn't share, or doesn't know) we will be here longer and longer.  Fortunately I am in a good spot right now. Letrozole in my drug of choice for now. Never seen my Oncologist come into the room SO happy! My body aches at places I didn't know would ache, but my numbers are down to 74!  My lowest ever. When it hurts to stand after sitting, I just think GO Letrozole, GO!  My scan last month showed less and less cancer, and many areas dormant. Sleep cells.. sleep...   I work really hard at my health with exercise and nutrition. I believe it pays off in the long run.  Also a thought to share that works for me. Very few people know that I have cancer. Family and a few close friends. I am fortunate enough to not have had chemo at this point. Thus, no "visual" evidence of hair loss that others would see. I chose this path as I want the privacy to deal with this in my own time and space. I feel VERY blessed to have this option, as I know many others do not have this choice.  By keeping my cancer to myself, the rest of the time to others I am just me. So each time I see someone I don't have to hear the "how are you doing, how are you feeling". Just trying to keep my life "normal" in a not so normal world that we all know.  Namaste to all.
Posts.Title: Invasive lobular Torridon MusicLover

Posts.Content: Jan 25, 2015 04:30PM MAW wrote: Touching base with us survivors... In the CA-27-29 monthly tests my last number was again in the normal range at 32. Feeling amazing! Truly "normal". I am taking an "adrenal supplement" (approved by my Oncologist) provided by my Chiropractor (who applies kinesiology for her treatment). It took my aches and pains for my bones and joints from an 8-9 down to a 2-3. Truly helped for me. Thought I would share with others. Last scan did not have anything to show. Got to skip the follow up Dr. appointment I am truly blessed. Namaste to all-

Posts.Content: Apr 18, 2016 08:37PM Maw-maw wrote: Maggerle cute dogs. I start Lymphedema therapy April 1/2. It's real simple. My swelling is minimal. 3/4 cm. and I wear compression sleeve most days. If you just finished chemo or rad that could be your swelling. We will have bouts of swelling. Caused by illness, infections, bug bites, eating salt. It's good to use our arms, they told me.Best wishes to you.
Posts.Title: Kicking LE's butt!! Exercise & Self Care Log Tina337 Flynn

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2014 03:03PM MAW wrote: I have been on Xgeva since original diagnosis 15 months ago. I have had no side effects from this shot, other than a sore arm for a day or so. I faithfully brush and floss my teeth to avoid as many teeth problems as possible. I feel very lucky.
